Keep in mind that not every team has a closer. Such teams do in fact save by committee, as for example last season's NL Champs did when Lidge broke down.

Those teams that do have closers, they know what they have: a pitcher who, 90% of the time you ask him to, finishes the game with your team on the winning side.

I've read armchair experts try to explain to the rest of us that the 9th inning is no different than any of the other 8.

Except that relievers themselves disagree with you. They admit when they don't have what it takes to be a closer, to be the man with the game in your hand on a regular basis.

And if there was nothing to it, then closers would not be so coveted nor paid so well, nor would several of them already be in the Hall Of Fame.

For pitching 50 innings a year.

I know it's hard to get your head around why (a) Jerry wouldn't use K-Rod in the 7th or 8th. (Answer: And who does he go to for those last three outs? His other closer?) And I know it's hard for you to get your head around why Jerry won't use K-Rod to start the 9th with a 4 run lead but will bring him in if the first two get on, even though it's still a 4 run lead. (Answer: Get this guy out or the tying run is at the plate. If you wait any longer, the inning might be in full flame. If you bring him in sooner, you run the chance of "wasting" him in a game where you never really needed him (the opposition was never in a position to tie the game in the 9th.)

And for those who need reminding: Big difference between warming up and actually coming in the game. Big, big difference.

I also read Krod popped off earlier this season about being used in non-save situations. You have to remember whom you're talking about. His actual pitching stats were inferior to other closers a couple of years ago, but he gained worldwide fame and immortality for accumulating a certain number of "regular season saves." He was with the Angels at the time who were far enough ahead in the standings that they could oblige Krod in never once pitching more than one inning the whole season. Krod was treated as a hero in Venezuela because of the "regular season total save stat." He said it was an extremely important record in his country. He's on a different team now, but probably retains an attachment to the "regular season total save stat" for obvious reasons.

The $ave rule may have been invented by a sportswriter but it got Krod his money, and it's how relievers get to Cooperstown.  So are you advocating that the closer comes in every time his team enters the 9th with the lead, no matter how big?  Well, surely not. So what lead is big enough?  Well, why don't we just go by the rule book and say the lead is big enough as long as the tying run is not on deck? Plus, Krod has a knack for making the mundane nerve wracking ,so it's just as likely he'd put two on himself starting the inning.  And recall that Randolph got criticized for bringing Wagner on in a non-save situation a few years ago.  So Manuel would get it for that too. I thought his logic was sound in that he wanted to avoid Krod because Felicano had gone two.  The rest of his bullpen, at the moment, is shaky and it's what Omar should be trying to acquire.

comments.commentBody: Looking at the pictures of you and your dad, Nick, you have your father's kind eyes and kind smile. But more importantly, you have his kind heart. Even if you never told him in so many words, I'm sure he knew how much you loved and respected him, and without a doubt he loved and respected his son. Peace to you and yours.

Your father was obviously a tremendous man.  Just to think how many people his life has lifted up, with all the students he taught and with all the people you have touched as a writer, thanks in part to his inspiration.  What a legacy.  That's an important thing to think about on this Father's Day.  So many Americans are having such a hard time in this economy, and there are so many others in dire situations all over the world.  It can be hard not to fixate on those things, and hard to remember to appreciate deeply the things that matter most.  Your dad's story is a lovely, hopeful thing.  Thank you for sharing it.  I'm very sorry for your loss.  May you and your family be surrounded by all the comfort and love you need.

Your Dad sounds like one of the most amazing, accomplished, and generous people who ever lived; thank you for sharing your memories of him with us! Though you'll never get used to Father's Day without him, I'm sure you'll continue to meet and hear from people whose lives he touched, and those stories will add to your appreciation of his tremendous legacy. (A library in a forest ... you couldn't ask for a better definition of heaven!)
Your father sounds like a wonderful man. Sorry for your loss.
Mr. Kristof, I share your loss, for your marvellous father and for mine.
I'm sorry for you lost.  He sounds like a wonderful man.  Blessings to YOU as a father, this Father's Day

Thank you for sharing this much of yourself and about your father. You know you were -- and are  -- fortunate, and that the loss is real and will persist. May you find support and healing among those who shared your love for him, and in your several communities of faith and compassion.

Mr. Kristof, this was a beautiful, eloquent tribute to your father, a remarkable man. I am so sorry for your loss, but know that the strength and resilience with which he lived his life is also a part of your character, and I hope this time of mourning is also one of celebration. His life is an inspiration, a triumph of survival and courage.
Thanks for this piece. It really is touching to read about your father. You were/are blessed.

My Dad died in December 2005 and I'm still sad when Father's Day and his birthday(November) roll around and more recently, Memorial Day. Our fathers had a lot in common. Carrying on legacies is important. See my post on Memorial Day at betsydrager.wordpress.com for my tribute.

Nicholas,

Not too late. Your dad is watching over you and knows just how proud you are of him!! You are lucky to have had such a wonderful loving family.

What an extraordinary and inspiring life! Thank you for sharing your father's story. I'm sure he has always been proud of you for extending his compassion and intelligence during your distinguished career. May your family always keep that long view from the cherry orchard in your hearts.
Great column about a great life. BTW, I can pronounce Vladislav Krsztofowicz. It's just those Polish Zs that confuse English-speakers.

Thank you for sharing these poignant thoughts with us at a moment when it is particularly hard to just breathe. It's a priceless gift, and much appreciated.

May the love of family and friends, and the nourishing memories of your wonderful family's life together, shorten the days of your grieving. May all that this fine man's life stood for give you all strength and comfort in the days to come -- most of all his very big heart and his wisdom.

Please know that many prayers and good thoughts will be surrounding you and your loved ones, from all over the world.

My sincere condolences to you and your family on the passing of your father. It is difficult to lose a great father and a great man; as it is also to be his son.

Blessings to you all
and Peace.

What a lovely statement from your Father -- and I see the thread that runs to you, too. My deepest sympathies -- it's such a monumental loss. My father died 6 years ago and I miss him every day. And his lessons in life, in love, in baseball, and about his beloved-but-flawed Catholic church stick with me, and I pass them along to my children. He was catholic with a little c and liberal with a giant L. (And Bronx/Brooklyn with a double B.)

My Dad was a big,big fan of yours, and would want to pass along this consolation from the Catholic rite of the funeral: "The life of those who are faithful to thee, Lord, is but changed, not ended." He's not gone from your life, just from this life. requeiscat in pace.
This is also my first Father's Day without my dad, who passed away a few days before Thanksgiving last year.
I have an idea now why you are the man that you are Nicholas. Your father was a great man and he raised another one.  My sympathy and keep up the world changing work that you do.
